blog.name: tusklovethebook
blog.title: Tusk Love, the Excerpts
blog.description:
THE SECOND SERIES FEATURED IS BY THE TALENTED WALLLFLOWERART

Tusk Love is Tal'Dorei's best-selling romance fiction novel series, first found by Critical Role's the Mighty Nein in the Chastity's Nook in Zadash.

The story of the second novel deals with the beautiful romance between Mizara, a trans half-orc woman with taste for the exotic and strange and Vulri, a hard-hitting go-getter who will stop at nothing to protect the love of her life.

They met on one of Hupperdook's many raves, and fell in love before the sun rose once more...

tags: --She has always supported this crazy endeavour; wanted to give her something. :P
summary:
Excerpt no. XVII of TUSK LOVE           Two days were two days too late for
Guinevere. Oskar spoke of patience as a much-needed...
caption:
Excerpt no. XVII of TUSK LOVE

         Two days were two days too late for Guinevere. Oskar spoke of patience as a much-needed virtue in times like those, but that only made her curse him even more. Oskar jested that he would not survive the end of the week if his contact did not meet them. Guinevere agreed.

         The cold of Icehaven reached through the winding alleys and slammed the door of the Hidden Inn open. Beneath the doorframe stood two figures of equal height, tall and broad. The candlelit room illustrated their features further as they closed the door and greeted the patrons and innkeeper with protests about how damn cold it was. Laughter ensued, albeit forced, and the figures picked up their drinks and walked towards the back of the room—towards Oskar and Guinevere.

         “Are those your contacts?” Guinevere whispered.

         “Can’t tell yet,” said the half-orc with narrowed eyes, “but they look like they might be, yeah.”

         The man sat down first, the bench in front of Oskar and Guinevere splintering under his weight. He pulled back his hood and smiled, baring his tusks to the half-orc sitting across for him. Oskar smiled back. They stretch out their hands, gripping the forearms like old battle companions. The woman followed the half-orc, sitting delicately rather than dumping her weight. She unwrapped her neck and face, dumping the frost covered scarf on the floor. Her lips were red, and her eyes were crowned by smoky shadows. Guinevere had never thought she would miss luxury such as that so much. The stranger’s rounded cheeks rose with a smile curling her lips.

         “Oskar, you sure know how to pick them. Just like Gram here, humans with a taste for danger.”

         “Elizabeth! Grammabash! It has been too long my friends.” Oskar grinned happily, quickly toasting to their health, yearning for their stories.

tags: i love farscape so much still
summary: Things I think about at 1 am... Critical Role edition
body:
Things I think about at 1 am… Critical Role edition

So if Vox Machina with their heroism and familial bonds lend themself to all the Star Wars AUs, The Mighty Nein are definitely more Farscape, bright and absurd and so very emotional.

I’m so glad I had someone to talk with about it, because I finally fell asleep right after sharing these thoughts. And now I need to think about possibly writing something…

blog.name: spontaneousmusicalnumber
blog.title: Avant-Garden
blog.description: Socially conscious fandom mess. Expect a good amount of anime, Dungeons and Dragons, social issues, and whatever else I find interesting. Who knows there's probably a velociraptor in here somewhere. A note about my posting style: I'll queue posts so they'll post evenly, but then fill up my queue and dump ten posts at once and take over your dash for a bit Icon by kakimari.

Solar Waltz by Cosmo Sheldrake is the Caduceus Clay song. Very soft and gentle, but a little off-sounding and definitely solarpunk. Also it includes this verse:

Like, if there’s a better song I’ve yet to hear it

summary: For those worrying about why Liam would be rolling a backup character
title: For those worrying about why Liam would be rolling a backup character
body: In a game where perma-death is possible, you should ALWAYS have a backup. Taliesin ran into that problem when Molly died and he didn’t have one and had to slap Caduceus together in a rush, and even complained about it on Talks. So don’t jump to conclusions.

reblog.comment: In a game where perma-death is possible, you should ALWAYS have a backup. Taliesin ran into that problem when Molly died and he didn’t have one and had to slap Caduceus together in a rush, and even complained about it on Talks. So don’t jump to conclusions.

trail.content_raw: In a game where perma-death is possible, you should ALWAYS have a backup. Taliesin ran into that problem when Molly died and he didn’t have one and had to slap Caduceus together in a rush, and even complained about it on Talks. So don’t jump to conclusions.
trail.content: In a game where perma-death is possible, you should ALWAYS have a backup. Taliesin ran into that problem when Molly died and he didn’t have one and had to slap Caduceus together in a rush, and even complained about it on Talks. So don’t jump to conclusions.
